moduleName: Sizes and Scales Earth and Moon
specificName: Sizes and Scales Earth and Moon
educationalObjectives: Students will learn the relative scale of objects in the Earth-Moon System
instructions:
You can navigate through this module by
clicking on the buttons floating above the Earth.  Select
the button with the laser and click on it with the trigger
to activate a button.

Next button - move forward in the module
Previous button - to repeat a previous section

When you have completed the simulation, you will be asked
to answer the questions in the lab handout.  Remember,
you can always go back if you miss some information.

When you are done, click the Red Next Module Button.
description: A scale model of the Earth and Moon
author: John Wallin

objects.tmp: {"textField": "Sizes and Scales of the Earth and Moon", "color": [255, 255, 255, 255], "fontSize": 1.0, "wrapText": false}

educationalObjectives: Explore how the rotation of the moon is related to its orbit.
instructions:
In the lab handout, go to the section on Synchronous 
rotation. Explore all the Moon Phases using the Next and Previous
buttons.  To active these buttons, select them with the laser 
and click on them with the trigger button.

Note how the robot's position changes as the moon orbits around the Earth.  
In the lab handout, draw a stick figure showing the direction
it is facing on at each phase. 

When you finish looking at all the moon phases, a red Next Module
will appear.  Click on this button to go to the next module in this lab.
description: A demonstration of synchronous rotation of the Moon
author: John Wallin

objectChanges.name: MainInstructions
objectChanges.canvasText:

specificName: Moon Phases as seen from Earth
educationalObjectives: Students will learn the sequence and appearance of Moon Phases as seen from Earth
description: Moon Phases as seen from Earth
author: John Wallin

objectChanges.name: MainInstructions
objectChanges.canvasText:
In the lab handout, go to the section on the
'The View from Earth.'  As before, explore all the Moon Phases using the 
Next and Previous buttons.  

In the lab handout, sketch how the moon appears as it is viewed from Earth.
You will not be grade on artistic abilty, but try to capture where the line
between the shadow and light part appears from this perspective.

When you finish looking at all the moon phases, a red Next Module
will appear.  Click on this button to go to the next module in this lab.

objectChanges.name: moonLabelTop
objectChanges.tmp: {"textField": "14 days after \n New Moon", "color": [255, 255, 255, 255], "fontSize": 1, "wrapText": false, "parentObject": null}

specificName: Earth Phases See From the Moon
educationalObjectives: Students will observe the phases of the Earth as viewed from the Moon
instructions:
In the lab handout, go to the section on the
'The View from the Moon.'  As before, explore all the Moon Phases 
using the Next and Previous buttons.  

In the lab handout, sketch how the EARTH appears as it is viewed from Moon.
You are actually diagraming "Earth Phases" instead of Moon Phases for this
part of the lab.

When you finish looking at all the Earth phases, a red Next Module
will appear.  Click on this button to go to the next module in this lab.
description: Earth Phases See From the Moon
author: John Wallin

objectChanges.name: MainInstructions
objectChanges.canvasText:

moduleName: The View From Above the North Pole
specificName: The View From Above the North Pole
educationalObjectives: Students will understand how moon phases appear from above the North Pole of Earth
instructions:
In the lab handout, go to the section on the
'The View from Above the North Pole.'  Once again, explore all 
the Moon Phases using the Next and Previous buttons.  

In the lab handout, sketch how the shadows on the Earth and Moon
appear from above the North Pole of Earth.  This is an unusual
perspective, but it helps clarify some of the diagrams you might
have seen in the textbook.

When you finish looking at all the moon phases, a red Next Module
will appear.  Click on this button to go to the next module in this lab.
description: Moon phases as seen from above the North Pole of Earth
author: John Wallin
